article.title: Cupola
article.paragraph: Inarchitecture, acupolaIPAc-enˈkjuːpələis a small, most oftendome-like, structure on top of a building.Cite webhttp://www.archiseek.com/guides/glossary/c.htmlGlossary of Architectural Terms - C3 January 2009Archiseek: Online Architecture ResourcesOften used to provide a lookout or to admit light and air, it usually crowns a largerroofor dome.Cite webhttps://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?qcupola26 April 2015The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language, Fifth EditionHoughton Mifflin Harcourt Publishing Company2014Cite webhttp://www.cupola.com/whatscu1.htmJust what is a cupola anyway?3 January 2009Cupola Consulting

The word derives, viaItalian languageItalian, from the lower Latincupula(classical Latincupellafrom the Greekkupellon) "small cup" (Latincupa) indicating a vault resembling an upside down cup.In Italiancupolasimply meansdome, and the ornamental top element is calledlanterna.

A cupola-stylecaboosewith anGlossary of rail transport terms#Aangel seataboveThe cupola is a development during the Renaissance of theoculus, an ancient device found in Roman architecture, but being weatherproof was superior for the wetter climates of northern Europe.cnFebruary 2015Thechhatri, seen inArchitecture of IndiaIndian architecture, fits the definition of a cupola when it is used atop a larger structure.cnFebruary 2015

Cupolas often appear as small buildings in their own right. They often serve as aBell towerbelfry,Belvedere (structure)belvedere, orroof lanternabove a main roof. In other cases they may crown aspire,tower, orturret.Barns often have cupolas for ventilation.cnFebruary 2015
The square, dome-like segment of a North American railroad traincabooseis also called a cupola.cnFebruary 2015
Some armored fighting vehicles have cupolas in the form of a raised dome or cylinder with armored glass to provide 360-degree vision around the vehicle.cnFebruary 2015
